title: Battlefield 4
review:
I sincerely don't recommend this game for multiplayer 
here are my reasons for it 

1st of all things the official servers are already closed down by ea (bcs they want you to buy bf5)
so when your official servers are down then why even bother selling your game especially at its original price as it
was back in 2013-14 it makes no sense
since on steam you can only buy premium edition that means you will definitely play multiplayer 
in fact most people are only buying to play its multiplayer and not single player
but nowhere is it highlighted or told in the game description or anywhere that the official servers have been shut down
i think this is stealing by showing the customer improper and selective information 
why arent you giving us all the details about your product when you are selling it advertising as "premium" or "ultimate" edition and selling it at sky high prices 

2nd that there are lack of asian servers 
its very hard to find a server that's close to your country if you are outside of europe & usa 
theres only team deathmatch servers running and thats not exactly the core of the game 
you dont want to play tdm with just 6 more players in this game
modes like conquest, rush, capture the flag and many more dont even have servers in asia
and if you want to play those modes you have to go in european or american servers where your ping will always be above 180 to 200 and with that much high ping you wont be able to enjoy this game there will be too much lag and you wont be able to focus at just about anything 

3rd point is that the admins of some servers are complete ret@rds and i seriously mean it 
i have been till now banned on 3 servers without any actual fault of my own 
1st server i killed the admin 4-5 times(i didnt know that he was an admin) from a helicopter and he burst into anger by writing abuses to me and then banned me 
i was like WTF ! 
how can someone have the power to ban you from the server ? even if hes an admin 
sure he has rented the servers from ea but that doesnt give him the right to ban players without any reason 
2nd i was banned almost immediately upon entering since i killed a player with a c4 
so there are some servers which have special rules like you cant kill from this gun this grenade this equipment or whatever
and if you do you get banned
3rd i got banned bcs the admin said that hes only going to allow players who are noobs or average 
seriously what in the fu cking hell is going with this game 
i dont understand the need for banning
why ban ? you can just kick the player out for a time being but having the power to ban from the server makes no sense
that would not be a big deal for me if the official servers had been up
but the official servers are down and then i got banned from rented servers too
so where the hell do i go now ?
i was really really p!ssed off by this 
you dont like someone just ban him from the server 
i cant even do something about this 
only power to ban should be with the anti cheat system
that is if you are using cheats you should get banned immediately and getting on that 
the anti cheat punkbuster doesnt work properly too
it kicks you out of the game randomly and does not detect real cheaters
i have been killed by cheaters in this game who can be easily detected as walling and using aimbots but no punkbuster instead creates problems for me instead of them 
so yeah what a great experience i had in playing bf4 multiplayer 
official servers are down there are no servers near my country and i get banned for stupid reasons in rented servers too 

why is there no review/appealing system for banning players from servers ?
it should be reformed into a kick system at the very best if you really want to stop others(for whatever reasons) from playing in your servers 
banning players for no reason should not be allowed and these servers should be taken down along with their admins

why are the official servers closed and yet the game is still being sold for its original price ? 
this is straight up stealing , you are advertising the product as "premium" yet you cant even use its contents 
its like selling a table but hiding that it does not have any legs or stands 
so its totally ineffective 

the answer is that ea does not give a damn about their player base and would do nothing about these issues
so when ea doesn't care about us then why should we care about their games

The game embodies battlefield, you can drive atvs full of c4 into an elevator and send them off a collapsing skyscraper, jump out of a jet while shooting an rpg at your opponent and land back into your jet taking control of it again, or you can bask in the chaos that is operation locker, a meat grinder of a map. This game has smooth and satisfying gunplay and it never gets boring.

title: Battlefield 4
review: I first played this game when I was a console gamer on PS3. At that time I couldn't seem find fun in the game. However when I got it on PC (Origin at the time), I fell in love with it. I'll be honest, the game still has many unfixed bugs and issues to this day, but still has a fairly active player base. Personally I feel this game is best when played with friends and I figure that is why I couldn't really get into it on console. Punkbuster is annoying and I've seen others get banned for things they did not do. Luckily if you get the message saying "Kicked by Punkbuster" its a fairly easy one time fix (Unless you are banned of course). All in all, I really love this game and I've put at least 100 hours on console and a good 850ish on PC. I recently bought it on Steam so I could centralize my games. A word of advice I have is be careful when playing multiplayer on a Punkbuster-enabled server while running any programs that could be flagged down by Punkbuster (I've heard cases of things like Torrent programs getting people banned). Also be aware that once you link an EA account with Steam that its currently impossible to unlink it without first getting help from EA's customer support (Which in my opinion is atrocious). If you don't have it its worth a buy but I will strongly recommend buying premium since you get priority when queuing up for a full server.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
It's a good game, but here's the issue. The campaign is short and the ai sucks. When you play on hard the friendly ai becomes autistic and can't hit anything while the enemy ai becomes bullet spongey as hell. I can't tell you how many times I died to someone throwing a flashbang because every single enemy throws one. 
The graphics and sound design are great, but that doesn't make up for the bad ai and artificial difficulty. I was disappointed because I played this on my old 360 and I don't remember it being this bad. Not to mention the amount of glitches with the world and the ai itself. At least 2 or 3 ai will sit somewhere and not move when your being attacked. The script just stops working for them so you have to go and look for the ai to finish the level. 
Now multiplayer. 
Multiplayer isn't bad, but not many people play it as much as they used to. 
I honestly can't recommend it which is sad because it's considered one of the better battlefield games next to battlefield 1. 
I found a gamebreaking bug on the level that you need to swim through the ship. To fix this, as soon as you start to not move or move backwords, pause the game for a few seconds and then continue the game and it should be fixed. You might have to do it a few times.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
7 years later, the multiplayer is still heavily populated, which proves my point that if you fix broken games with potential, people will come back and play it for years to come (unlike the new COD MW and BFV, which are super fun sometimes, but also super frustrating most of the time, with the developers having 0 intent to fix the frustrating elements).  While Battlefield 3 and before had awful netcode plus 10hz servers, DICE after Battlefield 4's bad launch decided to finally fix the netcode that plagued the game, which to this day has one of the best netcodes of any multiplayer shooter (Playing on European servers on BF4 with 100 ping is somehow a better experience than playing US servers on COD MW that are near my house).

It feels like the developers actually played Battlefield 2 before making this game, unlike Battlefield 3, and Battlefield V with Battlefield 1942.  From Battlefield 3, the game adds voice chat, 5 player squads, commander mode, and three factions instead of two, reminiscent of Battlefield 2 (They even re-added Dragon Valley).  While the newer Battlefield games are alot more casual than Battlefield 2, this game IMO has a good mix where the solo player experience is enjoyable, but playing as a coordinated squad can singlehandedly win games.

I would actually get this on Origin if possible, since the price is usually cheaper, you can add it to steam in order to use the Steam Overlay, and you can use the web server browser to join games instead of the ingame UI (which is horrible since servers can now spoof playercounts).

title: Battlefield 4
review:
For a seven year old game that has had three sequels Battlefield 4 is surprisingly alive in the Australian/OCE community, often there are 2-3 fully populated servers and a couple half empty with some running all the DLC (which you get from the Steam purchase) or just running classic maps. So the game is definitely not dead and still playable.

Content wise, at the price I bought it at $20 AUD, it gave me 60 odd hours of gameplay on top of the many more hours I've had on Xbox 360 and Xbox One (1300 hours roughly) and it hardly gets stale, I would honestly keep playing if it wasn't for the two elephants in the room.

As a new player and reliving that experience now, there are some fields that you will be at a heavy disadvantage as a newbie, vehicle gameplay heavily relies on using ECM/Active Protection and not having it is basically shooting yourself in the foot. On the contrary infantry gameplay as a new player is not difficult, the starting weapons are decent, although some are a bit weird to grasp at first (U-100). Due to the permanent 2x XP I recommend not buying the shortcut bundle because it is easy to get all weapons/vehicle upgrades within 40 hours of gameplay. 

So with all the positive points done, lets get on to those aforementioned two negatives:

The first elephant is the community, being a seven year old game there are some veterans of the game who cannot fathom that a new player (or returning player) is not 100% perfect in their actions and will easily shit-talk in chat or in voice communications. It is really sad to attempt to help a player to only be called a f***** and be told to f*** off when trying to repair their vehicle. On the flip-side, if you are doing well, you are obviously a hacker and prepare to receive constant abuse thrown at you. This abuse is above the basic salt after being killed and evolves further in trolling/griefing.

The second elephant in the room is the lack-luster anti-cheat systems in the game. The official system is punkbuster/fairfight, once you get fair fight banned the signature of your cheat is recorded and if another player uses the exact same cheat that player will be banned. The only significant issue with this system is that if the script is slightly changed, it produces a new signature and one can get around the system, it's not effective at all. I visited a cheat forum and learned that the only thing needed to change a signature was to rename methods and variables to be unique.

The second system is BF4DB which is a statistics based/manual report platform. Players can offer admins evidence of hackers to get them banned or the statistics of a player can show indication of scripts. There are two issues I have experience with this: (1) some hacks will never be caught in their statistics, like fire rate hacks or wall hacks is hard to detect with this system (after witnessing a cheat like this, and going to their clean BF4DB page there was no evidence of it apart from a high KD ratio) and (2) a players stats can be heavily skewed if they join:
- Modded servers (SPM, Damage, KPM and KD ratio are affected)
- Hardcore servers (Damage, KPM and KD ratio are affected)
- Boosting servers (all statistics, depending on what a player needs to grind)
- Locker/Metro servers (Accuracy and KPM)

BF4DB is not perfect in my experience in dealing with hackers and it can't be without being invasive but my experience with both the community and the cheaters has given me less fun with this game.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
From it's engaging multiplayer to a speechless campaign (quite literally), Battlefield 4 is one of the best FPS Shooters out there that everyone needs to experience. After racking up 1000 hours on the Xbox 360, I was finally able to experience Battlefield 4 on PC thanks to EA moving games from Origin to Steam (best decision). As of right now, there are still many servers up and running with 64 players in every region. Battlefield 4 contains heaps of Easter Eggs that you can activate which unlocks 2 DICE Developer Camos. This is also the case with the Phantom Program which unlocks the phantom bow (sadly never experienced it). Battlefield 4 is one those games that is slowly dying out but it's so slow that it isn't noticed. 

It's still fun, just get the game
9/10

title: Battlefield 4
review:
So it's not like I'm not having fun with the game. I'm sure I'll probably play multiplayer and that will be fine. I'll probably slog through the campaign too (and boy is it a fucking slog, more on that later) and it'll be fine. 

 The last Battlefield game I played the crap out of was 3. It was amazing. The campaign was not great but it was serviceable as a tutorial and felt good to play despite not being the main draw. It did it's job.
Battlefield 4 saw the devs (or let's be real, the coked up yuppies at EA) just not even finish most of it. It seems like they got a series of levels pasted together and didn't bother with even the most basic of tuning. They added a bunch of lens flare (Christ, the lens flare) and said "it looks great, people are only playing it for the multiplayer anyway." but they neglected SO FU(KING MUCH stuff that parts of it feel like I'm playing a Digital Homicide game.  Stuff you can't kill until the scripted event starts, levels that are basically rail shooters, other stuff I can't quite remember, but I remember cringing away from the screen quite a bit.  Like I said, only parts of it feel that way, but I've always considered Battlefield to be the standard of quality for FPS games period. That's why this was such a shock to me, I guess.  

And this is only how I feel about the game itself. I haven't even gotten to the steam "migration" port. It's really bad. It's very bad. I don't really know much about what I should be blaming on the porting process and what is jank left over from release, but I'll go over a thing or two that doesn't SEEM like it was in the final release of the console/origin release and IS in the steam release: There are game breaking bugs that require a restart on each level I have played so far. Most are scripted events that don't trigger, one was my own incompetence.   I have to assume that the guy saying "GIVE ME A TARGET" is a bug because there's no way that made it through testing without people killing themselves. There's a lot of times I just died and had to immediately restart a scene. Before you tell me to get good, one of the times was on the beach and I just fucking immediately died. I didn't get a chance to get my weapon out just POW...merc'd.  There are a LOT of times where it feels like the GAME is killing you not the enemies (either a bug or a really bad balancing issue) like, if you aren't going the right way or venture into a different part of the level you just get one shotted. I know it's not an exploration game, but dawg I was just trying to flank, not go for a stroll. 

Anyway. 

It't a good  multiplayer game, like you'd expect. But the campaign is VERY far below standard and the port is just trash. I hope they fix it, but I know they won't. I'm pretty glad I got it on sale. I wouldn't recommend it otherwise.

title: Battlefield 4
review: As a word of note to everyone reading this for a recommendation, buy it you'll love it and it can be very optimized HOWEVER* do NOT and I do mean NOT every change your display settings to borderless or change your graphics to Mantle, The game will refuse to launch after you close it with both of these settings or with just one or the other turned on, I had to experience 4 hours of pain to fix it, to those who have the issue, go to your bf4 doc, go to prof_save (if you need more help there is a bunch of help online) and scroll down to Fullscreen enabled and if its 1 make it 0 and if its 0 make it one and make sure if it says "mantleenabled" switch it to "mantledisabled", there could be several other issues but I promise you there is a solution for every possible problem online, especially on the EA forums. Besides that clusterfuck that are the display settings this game is still populated (avg of 200 - 500 players, mainly BF4 LC, SC, Rush, Air Sup and Oblit) and although only running on third party servers, is still fun as hell to play. And I mean, the campaign is there, not the best storyline in the world but unlike BO3 or BO4 there's actual character development. Game is still worth its 60 USD however its much better at 20 - 30 w/premium as it is about 7 years old.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
Exactly how it was, and people still play, except on Steam! Log in with your Origin account if you used to play on PC and get all of your progress loaded up! 

I've simply not gotten enough of this game. I have played it on PS3, Xbox One and PC for hundreds of hours and could not have enjoyed any moment of it more. From the sick 600m headshot to the pure rush of capturing an objective and holding off the enemy team with your squad, this game still brings the thrills I look for every time I play it. With every type of warfare, you won't be out of options or areas to improve on. 

For a more meaningful gameplay experience, make sure to use the server browser as the tool it is so that you can find the servers that you want to play on. Don't settle for quick match, or you'll end up sorry you started playing. Get some of your friends to get the game and squad up, makes all the difference! 

See you on the Battlefield!

title: Battlefield 4
review:
Before you get this game, make sure you have PunkBuster installed! You cant play multiplayer without it. After installing the latest version, simply add BF4 into it. Now on to the review. 

This game has to be one of the best grand scale multiplayer FPS games I've played in a while. The gunplay is really nice and satisfying when you get kills or assist your team in capturing an objective. The progression system even incentivizes more gameplay and to try out new weapons and tactics. Team play is paramount to ensure victory. There are also steep but rewarding learning curves for piloting aerial vehicles and sniping. 

However, if you planned to get this game purely for the single player campaign, then you will surely be disappointed. The campaign is a buggy and unfinished mess with a story you find on any C list action film with very 1 dimensional characters. 
The only upside to playing the campaign are the weapons you unlock for multiplayer, which are fantastic by the way, and the ability to gun down PLA soldiers. As a local and resident of Hong Kong, it brings me great pleasure to mow down hordes of commie bastards and hear them wail in agony in their mother tongue as they draw their last breath. Take THAT, Pooh Bear. 

Battlefield 4 also has an abundance of loot boxes. These loot boxes can be bought or earned with gameplay, which lock certain crucial weapon attachments behind them. I hate loot boxes and I shall never support them as they are a horrible and unethical business practice. 

The customization menu has been removed from the in game UI and placed on a website. How stupid.

Overall, despite the shoddy singleplayer and lootboxes, I still recommend getting this game ONLY at discount price. The amount of content you get on the Steam version seriously trumps the Origin version as you get EVERYTHING for half price. On top of that, you get one seriously fun and engaging multiplayer experience.

review:
Almost 7 years old game still alive with huge community. Great fun for many of hours. Many of players coming back to BF4 'cause of dev stopped support BFV. Plenty of servers with diffrent maps and modes full of players. Everyone can find something for themselve.

Pros :

- Still alive, plenty of full servers
- Fantastic multiplayer mode
- Massive content with including all dlc's
- Lots of weapons and customizations
- Graphic, game still looks great
- The destruction of the environment still looks great

Cons :

- Short and weak campaign for single player
- No many players in game when it's very early or late time
- Little high price as for 7 yr old game

I'll keep it short. 
Battlefield Bad Company 2 is still the best game they've made. Somehow, BF4 fails to get the little things right.  Like sound..  How is a tank standing 10 feet from me, firing away without my interface giving me a clue?  Footsteps..  Remember them?  
In Bad company2 you could face north and hear a shot fired from half a map away and know where and what direction the shot was going.  You could hear soldiers moving around you before you saw them.  I'm just shocked at how wrong they got this..

title: Battlefield 4
review:
Honestly one of my all time favorites.

Pros:
- Fun with friends
- Still servers up
- ACE CQB
- Vehicle gameplay is fun when you are coordinating with your gunner/driver
- The MBT's are just as fun as I remembered!
- Heli gameplay is ok, but there are people who have a lot of experience doing this one thing who will knock you out of the sky in an instant.


Cons:
- All servers are third party, DICE servers are practically non-existent which leads to a lot of bruised egos and annoying communities
- About the community. You'll meet some amazing people, but there are a lot of toxic elements who ruin the game. They are pretty much the average neckbeard.
- Gunplay. I'm, really torn on this one. Sometimes it's very crisp and smooth and others it feels like I'm shooting rubber bullets. In addition to this, it feels like the gun is jamming. Never had this happen on console, but at the same time I wasn't able to spam my LMB at targets.
- ACE CQB

8.2/10
Get at this price, not a dime more

review: To put it politely, the game is dead. It's been years since BF4 released, and each new battlefield game has taken a portion of its players. Now, the vast majority of servers are artificially seeded with fake players, boosting player counts to game limits while only having 2-4 real players. The secondary servers the game is now hosted on lead to severe packet loss, and lag as a result. Its the same fun battlefield it always was, but the life of the game is now nonexistent.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
For those having Punkbuster kicking you out of server problems like I had, there are a bunch of guides on steam to fix this and It worked out well for me. So before you play multiplayer, go to the user guides for this game and get yourself oriented with it first.

Anyways, Battlefield has always been (At least, to me) a better mutliplayer game than single player. Call of Duty is the other way around for me. Each of the two series has opposite problems but overall, I have always liked Battlefield because it involves skill and not luck like Modern Warfare or Black Ops does.

So how is Battlefield 4? It's a huge sprawling mutliplayer game that I'm really getting into again after a few years. I had this game on Origin and enjoyed playing it but now that I've come back I realised I am not only better at the game than I was before, but this is probably my favourite Battlefield game DICE has made.

I'm still ranking up in this game as I'm on Level 6/Rank 6, but so far, I love using most of the weapons and unlocking them. The Bolt Action Sniper you start with in Recon class really had me getting lots of kills and enjoying how the game feels. People are not trying to do stupid No Scoping techniques or rushing into battle getting themselves killed and none of the people are really mic spamming like in COD, Battlefield 4 has a good community that knows what tactics to use and when to fight. Suppression is huge in this game and becomes a great tactic to intimidate players to move back from objectives which is absolutely great. 

The best part I feel is you don't even need to kill people in order to be good at Battlefield 4, Suppressing Fire, Kill Assists, Capturing Points, it all gives you points and at the end of the game you get ranked with Ribbons and all that. You don't need to kill one single person in order to get good which makes it very accessible for those new to Multiplayer shooters.

But how is the campaign? It's surprisingly better than I thought it was originally. Although it's incredibly glitchy and DICE probably will never fix these bugs, the campaign is surprisingly really good. I really enjoyed the banter of your military buddies and the guns felt very impactful and it feels like a war zone out there. Also, it's way different than fighting Bad Guy Russians in COD Campaigns, you actually fight the Chinese at one point in this game and it feels very refreshing. If there was one thing I can give Battlefield's campaigns, their characters are more in depth and more likeable than in recent COD Games. Even in Battlefield V from what I played the characters are really good. So I do recommend this campaign in particular but be aware it's buggy.

If you like Battlefield, the multiplayer in this is a no brainer. I am having a very fun time with this game and I love leveling up my multiplayer character and earning new weapons and ribbons. If you are curious about the campaign, I say go for it. You might end up really liking it. It's better than most of the recent COD Campaigns nowadays and it was certainly better than Ghosts when it came out.

Overall, I like it. Beautiful graphics that still hold up, solid gameplay, lots of customization, good community so far from what I've seen, big maps to explore and a campaign that is actually quite good.

title: Battlefield 4
review: Battlefield is here on Steam. What does it offer? Well, the same. It's Battlefield and servers are own by players or other third-parties. This game still uses Origin software so be on the lookout for that. Punkbuster installs like normal. You may find though certain gamemodes are unpopulated, they're just the niche ones like gun master, you can find Conquest and TDM. Sadly classic modes like Rush are dead. I'll give this 7/10 for having players be active on this somewhat old game unlike certain call of dutys (COD IW lmao).

title: Battlefield 4
review:
Battlefield 4 Is an amazing game, one of the greatest of the series imo, I have soaked so many hours into thid game on Xbox and after its come to Steam on sale I couldn't resist, the campaign is certainly a fun experience that will take up many hours of your time, but if your looking to play multiplayer you must look beyond the steam port of the game, the PunkBuster anti-cheat is absolutely horrid and most servers will kick you after a minute because the anti-cheat is firing off faster than me every sunday night. I will delete this review if the issue becomes fixed, but your better off just getting the game via Origin.

YOU CAN FIX THE ISSUES WITH PUNKBUSTER!!!!
It is unfortunate that you have to fix this, but it is possible to play this game online, you must go to https://www.evenbalance.com/pbsetup.php and update the punkbuster anti-cheat and then it'll let you play, for some people thats enough, for people like me you'll also have to add the game to punkbuster using the same installer, it is very quick to install and well worth the effort.

EDIT: Problems are resolved and the game works perfectly fine out-of-the-box. Thank you EA.

review: kinda sucks that all these servers are community run. title: Battlefield 4
review:
Very glad to see that this game has come to Steam after countless hours years ago with the Xbox 360 and Xbox One versions. The graphics completely outrun plenty of titles today and are optimised superbly, holding up a constant and unchanging 60FPS on ultra settings but Steam was still calculating upwards of 140FPS if my monitor could run that high.

I re-played the story first and foremost to remember the great characters, the levels look brilliant and honestly the only issues I had during gameplay were EXTREMELY TINY glitches in the campaign such as with movement, but these were as I said, TINY, and were in no way gamebreaking.

For multiplayer, it's still populated, fun as ever, especially with all the expansions free and as I remember; extremely rewarding with the battlepack system. The community is fun to engage with (both literally and in the sense of in chat) and games always turn out as fun whether you win or lose.

7 years later, I still LOVE this game and I think I'll be sitting on it for years to come, even after Battlefield 2021 is released.

EA's decision to move the Battlefield Franchise onto Steam is a clear sign of Origin's failure to even catch up to what Steam is able achieve and to think that EA advertised Origin as an endgame to Steam hasn't aged well. In any case, it is without a doubt that the Steam release for BF4 showed how many players were willing to game on it without having to deal with another stubborn platform. 

BF4 is the real deal, the unpolished gem that was BF3, is perfected in 2013 and its legacy is still alive today with a healthy server population.  Oceanic Servers have seen a dramatic rise in player count with the steam release as opposed to back then when Oceanic servers were only populated on weekends. At the current price, BF4 Premium is worth every cent and no doubt the last best BF entry with how mediocre BF1 and BFV was. 

Get it while you can, you won't regret it.

title: Battlefield 4
review: I wanted to play this game again. I have over 300 hours on the xbox one and some of my best gaming memories have been of BF4. Unfortunately, at least for me, pings for all servers are at least in the 1000's and in some cases reached 2.8 billion. Some will say "uhh thats obviously your internet, not the game." I would agree if this was standard for my other games but this isn't. The few servers I did join I was kicked immediately by admin for what? I'm not sure. Maybe it's because I'm listed as a lvl 1... I would like my bipod knife back as I had grown quite fond of the massive bipod sticking out of my victims chest. Anyway, be wary if you decide to buy this game. Unfortunately this game is not like it used to be.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
I'm running multiplayer on:

Shitty internet connection
medium settings, 1280x720 59hz
930m 2GB vram
i5 5200
8gb Ram

and it works great. there's a couple of servers in HK, CN, JP with acceptable ping up to 120ms (i'm from SEA). with that graphic settings im getting stable 30-40 fps depends on the player count. For example, Op Locker map with 40+ players im getting 30 fps at least.

What you should do before buying this:

Better to buy it on sale
You have origins installed and running before you press the Play button. Otherwise it will take a while to launch.
Check the guides section of the game for that punkbuster fix.

As the other fellow pointed out, yes there's plenty of server to play for SEA players, 
6 hours in and i've reached level 9. it has been a smooth experience so far. havent encounter any serious hackers yet.

title: Battlefield 4
review: Nice FPS game with shiny graphics. I like weapon customisation in multiplayer mode and that was missing part in BF3 (not too many attachments for weapons in BF3)....if u like big maps, all sort of vehicles, freedom of choice in approaching and killing the enemies this is a game for you. I recommend this game....if I need to rate this game from 1 to 5 it would be a limp 4, because there is weird glitches and bugs.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
I've played every BF game from BFBC2 onwards and BF4 is the best one by far.
BF4 may have the biggest playerbase of any BF game on PC and that is only going up with BF5 losing support.

If you've never played BF4 or not played it for a long time:

- Game now uses in-game UI like BF5 (no weird browser battlelog garbage)
- Game only has community servers afaik (no official Dice / EA ones)

Things to note for the Steam version at time of writing:

- Requires Origin (doesn't bother me)
- Only premium edition is available, is a bit pricier than keys you can find for Origin
- Has trading cards but no achievements

title: Battlefield 4
review: I love Battlefield 4, I consider it the last great battlefield game. I played a ton of hours on it when I had my old 360. The singleplayer campaign is still a great campaign despite it's age. However I cannot play multiplayer because the steam version of the game doesn't include the up to date Punkbuster needed to not get kicked. The fact I have to manually install the new Punkbuster anti-cheat system in order to play multiplayer is bogus. Also the fact you have to have Origin is another slap in the face. Why the **** do you need Origin to run the "Steam version"? Great game, I love it but because the port is so freaking terrible, I have to give it a negative review. It's a shame because BF4 doesn't deserve negative but the crappy port by EA makes it terrible.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
~This is only a recommendation for people who DO NOT already own BF4 on PC at all...~
- I mean yes Its battlefield 4 exactly how I remember it, An amazing 10/10 game for its time and honestly even now.
- That being said I am disappointed owners did not get a steam key. There is not really an excuse, It uses Origin to launch anyways and keeps progress, But no just because you'd 
rather play it on your preferred platform you gotta pay for that.
- Also on a side note this game has very little active servers, I only bought it because I saw a youtube video where a guy was saying that it has been reborn, This really is not true. There is enough players KIND OF, But you'll be stuck to only playing certain maps or modes so goodbye to any hope of completing some challenges. (I did not have it installed anymore on Origin and my internet is very slow 128Kbps Rural connection so it was sort of more worth it to just download on steam anyways, I don't regret it really but it does kinda feel like wasted money, If you already own it. To bad EA does not care about us loyal fans)
- I wish they added Steam achievements... Even if it was just a port of the Origin achievements. Why not?

title: Battlefield 4
review: You can't go wrong with bf4 on steam. It's just good old Battlefield 4 but on steam. It's fun as hell, it is the last good battlefield imo. Just download punkbuster, that's it, it is not very hard it took two minutes. The negative reviews are mostly complaining about a fix that takes 2 minutes and the fact that origin exists. They're shallow complaints and none actually pertain to the gameplay itself. The game is fun although the first few days are brutal due to not having anything unlocked. But regardless the game is fun, ignore the meaningless negative reviews. If you can't take an extra two minutes to install punkbuster then that is fine but don't review bomb an actually great game. For those who are worried about whether the game is populated, for me at least living in the U.S. there are always servers.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
Battlefield 4 is a game of 32 v 32 PvP battles over large scale maps where the player is given four classes to choose from (Assault, Engineer, Support, and Recon) with a little bit of weapon customization (Much more than what BF1 or BF5 has to offer, but still nowhere close to something like Escape From Tarkov) and gives the player access to Land Vehicles like Tanks, Jeeps, AA, LAPVs, and Bikes, Water vehicles like Jet skis, RHIBs, and armored boats, and Air Support like Transport Choppers, Attack Helis, and Jets. That all are used on a large play area with destructible environments. 

I've played countless hours of this game on Xbox One, PS3, and on PC before it came to steam, and for a game that released in 2013 and hasn't seen much major updates since the CTE content, its still very much so active.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
ba dum bum badumdum

It's a great game. Like usual, the best moments are during huge firefights with dozens of people on either side just throwing everything they can at each other, tanks rolling in, blowing shit up, then getting destroyed, planes & helis swooping in to fire or crash, the environment crumbling around you, nobody knowing what the fuck is going on and just praying they don't die. While BF1 is more my speed, there's no resisting that Battlefield magic, no matter what time period it's in.

Also literally all you need to do is manually download punkbuster first, that's it

title: Battlefield 4
review:
One of the greatest Battlefield titles out there. Me and my old xbox buddies spent hours playing this, we always had a blast. Nostalgia 100 

Pros:
-The game offers a huge and diverse way to customize your solider-from 4 different types of weapons (The class gun, Carbine, DMR, and Shotgun), as well as customization for attachments on primary and secondary weapons-not to mention equipment. This also goes for vehicle equipment customization perfect for what role you want for your vehicle (and solider) to have in the battlefield.
-Single player is pretty good, action packed and decently long.
-Map design is incredible-large and immersive maps make it fun and give it a realistic touch to it.
-$19.99 for the entire game + DLC. not to mention free battlepacks.
-Servers are still very active, making it easy to find a game.

Cons:
-You need to donwload punkbuster for you to play multiplayer. Cool thing is, is that it's very very easy and quick to download-took me about 5 min. There are guides as well to show you how to download it.  
-You have to download Origin Launcher as well/make an account if you do not have one. But who cares.
It is a shame to see that people are giving this game negative reviews just for that reason(s)

review:
Alright so where should I even start, If you want a short answer then: Buy the game right fucking now lol

But for those of you who wish for explanation, Then here we go.

I have over 700 hours on the game, Unlocked almost every single content in this game, Did every assignment (Easter eggs too)
Got almost every single content the game has to offer for me and i'm still having fun! Bf4 really reminds of of Bf2, The maps, Vehicles, And the really neat and fun "Commander mode" really adds to the game, The game is good, Beautiful, Really replayable and super fun when teamwork kicks in, It's pretty much a semi-reskinned Bf2, It has something for all FPS players, You should definitely try it.

All and all, Excellent game.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
I appreciate the background and design of this game but the current game (at least for the steam version) contains several other problems apart from the PunkBuster one. Here are some of them: 

1. The in-game server browser only displays a fraction of all the available server: This problem is particularly frustrating for players in Asia and Oceania (only showing few empty servers when there are 4 to 5 active servers). I have to search for a game using the battlelog instead.

2. Often experiencing server lag: Server lag often happens to all the players in the same server and even to other servers in the same region. Players claimed that this is because of DDoS attacks.

I don't recommend buying this game on steam before the above problems are fixed.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
Have been playing this game before it got released on Steam. Many people mention that - the last good Battlefield, and I agree. Love the gameplay, even though sometimes it's unbalanced and some admins are banning for no reason.

Reviewers claim issues with Punkbuster, when I was installing BF4 I've gotten the Punkbuster installation prompt, so maybe this got fixed (there are still tutorials if it's not fixed).

I am very disappointed in both EA for doing that and Valve for allowing this in many games - forcing players to use third-party launchers. Some games like GTA V have an abridged version of a launcher, but BF4 uses a full version of Origin. Why? Why do we have to have an account on the Origin, Uplay, Rockstar Social Club etc. etc. to play a game which is being sold on Steam already? The revenue share argument is no longer valid because the game is being sold over Steam so Valve is taking the cut anyway. Some titles have cross-play no matter what platform it's on.

The game is great, hence the positive review. Not sure about the price, I'm think that already discounted Â£20.00 is too much for a 7 year old game, which have been for free a few times in the past.
And for ***** sake, PORT THIS GAME TO STEAMWORKS EA/DICE.

Now, what are my thoughts of BF4 after i found a fix? It's one of my favorite shooters of all time. title: Battlefield 4
review:
It runs an Origin thin client, and at least on release requires you to go the Punkbuster site and manually install the anti-cheat. Not that the game tells you that until getting kicked from lobbies - you just have to know that incompetence is in the air and crawl the reviews for the solution.

It's an incredibly expensive game on Steam but off-sale $40 is a joke for a 2013 shooter... Which tend to get tossed aside in favor of sequels and have dwindling playerbases, kinda the case here. Much like BFBC2, and BF3, this just doesn't have a ton of life left in it, you aren't going to be sticking around here for years unless your tastes line up with the most popular flavor of Conquest Large. Doubly so if you're in one of the areas in the world that this game isn't as popular. The game has been followed up by Hardline, BF'1', BFV - Not to mention the Star Wars entries. and it paints a pretty clear picture that DICE/EA want you there, instead of here.

BF4 is alright, thumbs down on principle. This thing ships broken. EA's public image has been dragged against pavement for very good reason and the shit-show never seems to stop.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
The gameplay is fun so I'll recommend it. 
But:
For the amount of money it cost to make this game, the campaign is really sloppy. All of the things that were never tweaked or reworked break the 4th wall a LOT. 
You play as a commanding officer who is completely silent. So, instead of writing dialogue for the main character, he just gets orders barked at him by one of his men. Your character doesn't need a voice because he has no thoughts or feelings about anything. The longer you go into the campaign the more glaring the problem becomes. It seems for the cost of production, couldn't they have had oh... anyone in the military give the script a read? The Player is the leader of a special ops team that ought to be in the Special Olympics.
The friendly AI is keyboard-snapping dumb to the point that you are fighting alone. They run in front of bullets (and rockets lol) and will continue to shoot the same wall that the last remaining enemy is behind until you decide to go handle it and get on with the game. 
The enemy AI also has magic powers. You have to complete the task the way the game wants you to or you will die. Repeatedly. Until you learn your lesson.
Your tank is destroyed but you can reach an area where the enemy tanks can't follow? Too bad. You're blowing up those tanks before we get back to the mission at hand. 

With all of the great things EA has ruined in its quest for money, they could at least take care of the games they still make.

review:
It's as you expect it to be for a EA game. And it's even worse now that it's on Steam. 

Me and my friend both had heavy amounts of troubles getting the game to work at first. To even start.(As of this review). Origin did not recognize my friend having owned the game and refused to start up. until he re installed the entire game.

Once in game. Joining servers is a huge burden. You'll be lucky to even get to join a game if you dont get error messages or "failed to connect" after trying to join servers. 

And if by some miracle you manage to join, you'll probably be kicked within the minute cause the shitty anticheat is the lowest budget shit and noone knows a proper fix for it. so have fun with that.

and by the time you get that fixed. you'll still have trouble joining due to errors and shitty matchmaking from EA. and if you're unluck like me. you'll have a succesful join once in a blue moon. but once that game is over. you'll have to go through 50 error messages trying to join a new server. 

Besides that. it's battlefield.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
It's Battlefield 4 on steam, what can I say?

- If you wanna start as a brand new soldier, create a new origin account and link that one, otherwise, link your current account and you'll still keep all the original progress you made on origin :)
- You may need to manually install Punkbuster, i did, i see a few others did, but it's worth it to play an epic gamer game, it comes with an old version when the game installs itself, so it'll kick you quite a bit until you install the new version.
- Community's still groovin, Plenty of people in Australia from what i can tell, a few full servers, pretty epic.
- Campaign is still a good play through if you're bored :)
- Trying to get into a game with friends was a bit hell, this might just be from my experience but once we did get into a game we had some fun, blew some stuff up.
- Still one of my more favourite battlefield games.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
This game is an absolute masterpiece and had DICE realised that this was what Battlefield fans wanted, the series would be in a very different place right now.  The only issue with this port(because the game is perfect) is the Punkbuster issue.  It is very easily solvable and many people have already posted the solution.  If you loved BF4 before, it is no different now and while the less popular maps and servers are not populated, you can easily find a game of vanilla maps conquest that is full or a 24/7 Locker or Metro that people still play on.  Most games I reminisce about and play years later end up being boring and the only reason I thought it would be good to play was because of the time in which I played it.  That's most games.  Not this game.

It still holds to this day, alive and kicking...

P.S DICE you have to make another modern Battlefield game, these were your glory days and if you want to return to them, you have to realise this.

10/10

The Perfect Game

title: Battlefield 4
review:
[h1] A (somewhat) Helpful Review [/h1]
Trash reviews all over the place. People complaining about stuff that takes a maximum of literally five minutes to set up. Play this god like game already.

[h1] READ IF YOU NEED HELP WITH PUNKBUSTER[/h1]
Go to the official punkbuster website by looking up â€œpunkbuster websiteâ€ then download the client for windows or whatever you have. Go through the download process and when its done, open it up and click on â€œadd game.â€ Make sure BF4 is installed or it might not work, but once you add it boom! Issue fixed. That took like what, 2 minutes? For those who wrote lazy reviews you couldâ€™ve spent your time actually trying to fix it quickly. Any other questions just comment on my profile. (Canâ€™t link punkbuster website cause itâ€™ll get removed)

Edit: There apparently is an issue where your punkbuster will not download the update, I aswell as others I talked to did not have this issue so I do not know how to fix it. I recommend doing research and if I find a solution I will add it above. The only possible solution I can think of is completely uninstalling punkbuster than manually reinstalling it, but yet this is not guarenteed to work.

[h1] OTHER INFO [/h1]
1. Yes, you need to install origin. But does that really matter? Itâ€™s 20$ for BF4 + ALL DLCS. (You also get 61 battle packs if you care, at least I did) It took me no longer than 3 god damn minutes to setup origin, you donâ€™t even need to use it afterwards! Just launch it through steam, both platforms are linked anyway.

2. Yes the game is still extremely active despite its age. (For users outside of North America and Europe, do some research on BF4 playcounts in your areas. They may be significantly lower). You will have NO problem finding a full 64 player match. DLC maps you might have an issue with as most are not as popular. Most popular servers are Conquest Large on base maps. Donâ€™t go for quick play and immediately go for the server browser. I personally have not found a server that lied to be about its playercount but if you do just test out all the servers and favorite legit ones so you can find them later, thatâ€™s what ide do.

3. System requirements size lies to you, the game takes up roughly 51GB instead of 30GB as they basically just mashed the DLCs into the premium edition.

4. â€œShould I buy the Ultimate Shortcu-â€œ [b] N O [/b] Waste of money. Youâ€™re literally paying half the price of the game to unlock some gadgets earlier. Also get the other free DLC, basically just more maps to mess around with.

5. â€œShould I buy this game?â€ [b] YES [/b] The multiplayer makes up 90% of the experience and its a damn amazing one. I bet many would agree with me. But be warned, if youâ€™ve never played battlefield your first few games will be hell but once you get used to it its all good. I recommend only running campaign if you got spare time or are achievement hunting. Donâ€™t get me wrong its not a bad campaign by any means but its nothing breathtaking either.

6. "Should I buy this if I already have it on Origin?" [b] NO. [/b] Steam and Origin users can play together and see the same servers. I also saw a user state in the comments that all DLCs will be given away on Origin for free at some point. Unless you have spare cash that you have absolutely nothing else to spend on, do not buy it on steam if you already have it on Origin.

Hope this review helped! If there are any mistakes I made please comment down below!

title: Battlefield 4
review:
One of my absolute favorites, you remember the times when EA DICE made some very good and decent games, like Battlefield 2142 which is my first favorite of the series and will always hold a special place in my heart as it gave me some more than decent memories and countless of hours spent with friends on various maps (Camp Gibraltar anyone?).

Anyways, I was reading through the reviews and it is getting bombed by people who have, in all honesty, simple issues with their anti-cheat program (PB - Punkbuster) but that can be solved very easily by visiting PB website and downloading their PB Setup and reinstalling thus repairing/updating the AC of the game.
Now the game itself is truly amazing, even by today's technical standards.

Now singleplayer campaign is a familiar FPS cliche that uses the 2007's Modern Warfare template and formula in a way, with story line that you will forget in no time, sadly. 
The action is set in 2020, six years after the events of Battlefield 3. The story arc follows a single squad, Tombstone, as the U.S. becomes embroiled in a war with a militaristic faction of the Chinese government. Russia and the U.S. have been fighting for six years, but war with China is imminent because of a spat with Admiral Chang, the main foe, who plans to overthrow Chinaâ€™s government and support the Russians in the war with the U.S.
But all that does not compensate for the impossibility of sending back the grenades, the characters without charisma, the very flat scenario, or the successful artistic direction but too generic. Even the presence of three different endings falls completely flat since they depend on only one final choice, and the difference between each of them is roughly limited to the three lines of dialog following the decision. a simple white circle indicating for example the presence of an interactive zone.

And that's alright because this game is played cause of it's amazing multiplayer aspect, while also being able to compete with 64 players and fluently on huge, magnificent, partially destructible, vehicle or infantry only maps.
DICE pushed the limit of FPS genre by creating one amazing physics engine with the concept of Levolution on any map and that combined with various weapons and vehicles gives this game that "all out war" feeling that will surely keep you entertained.
Commander mode is there but since this is, after all a fairly old title of 7 years now, not many are using this feature.
Now I know that the graphics and physics aspect of any game is important as is in this one but certain maps are done in such a way that DICE devs never really accounted for another team to be trapped. One of those maps that I played a lot of is OP Locker. It's a great map with and interesting design in mind with snowy environment and snow storms on the outside of the facility but either team can easily become basetrapped and then you have to rely on active admins or server enabled scripts to initiate a so called "nuke" feature so that dominant team backs off from the last objective that is nearest to the base.

Like in any FPS game where reflexes and attention to the minimap and your surroundings is vital for you and your team, so is the cheating problem.
FF (FairFight) and PB ( Punkbuster) work in a combo, one is client side and other is serversided, statistical checking and screenshot validation, checking for wallhacks, etc. I would like to add that there is also an independent team of mods and admins who are in control of BF4DB site where suspected cheater can also be reported with sufficient evidence and every case is thoroughly reviewed. 
Even with these three people still manage to creep around with their hacks and get banned by AC or BF4DB or active admins on a server. With that in mind it is important to find a good server with active admins, preferably an active, larger community that runs servers in this game and play there.

Battlefield 4 Premium on Steam is a nice addition although I think it is a bit late, players are very active and playerbase is still fairly large, certain maps are played more than others so keep that in mind when hoping for some action on certain maps. Locker and Metro are absolute favorites atm and most player congregate and play on those maps.
Cheating issue is present, like in any FPS game, but can be avoided by playing on famous, community supported servers with active staff/admins.

Servers vary in so called "tickrates" - Server come in various tick rates,  30Hz ~ 60Hz ~ 120 Hz
*Tick rate refers to the amount of times a server performs gameplay-related calculations each second. With a Battlefield server, one of the many calculations performed during each tick is hit detection; this is usually what people are referring to when they complain about tick rate.

It's important not to confuse this with the update rate, which is the amount of times a server sends gameplay information (updates) to your client each second. There is also a command rate, which is inversely, how often your client sends its information (commands) to the server.

At the time of it's release it's main competitor was Call of Duty: Ghosts. DICE has had their fair share of issues with this release and EA didn't make it any easier for them at the time of release.
If you want to experience some solid FPS actrion which is set in modern time and which is different than CoD in a way, then give this game a try. Expect explosions, random hit detection on 30Hz servers, some salt from enemy teams and even teammates, 140 levels, 4 classes with various weapons and attachments, many vehicles, etc.
After almost 7 years ( 4000 hours spent in game) and various issues that plagued this game from it's less glorious start, I still play it and always return to it, heck this must be the first game I install when I finish building a new PC or when formatting a fresh Windows.

*P.S I already owned a copy on Origin client, so I didn't know what will happen once I buy the Steam version of the same game. 
Once purchased and downloaded (41 GB or so) the Steam client will ask you to connect your existing Origin account, if you have one ofc, and then once it connects the Steam and Origin accounts you will have a Battlefield 4 Steam version of the game in your Origin client. Neato. 
The stats/emblems and all the unlocks/ranks that you had on Origin version of the game will be transferred and connected to the Steam version so there's that too.

The only thing left to say is happy fragging and charge your defibrillators to full 100%. :)

title: Battlefield 4
review:
Oh how good it feels to be back
after playing BF4 both on PS4 and XBONE with roughly 400hrs between the two, I found myself missing the game and picked up a copy as soon as i heard it was on steam. finally. 
Now that being said, I've been seeing a lot of people complain that you've got to download both PunkBuster and Origin to play it, but let's be real here, if you're going to spend a minimum of $20 on a game on PC, you can suck it up and take the 3 minutes it takes to download both. And seriously if those 3 minutes it takes to download something really bug you so bad as to leave a bad review, maybe consider reviewing the gameplay instead of pissing in the wind. Reviews are here to review the game, not the things you've got to install with it. And on that note, on to gameplay!

Battlefield 4 offers some of the best large scale battles I've had the pleasure of taking part of, be it a gritty close combat fight in the halls of Locker, A fight in the skies of Giants of Karelia (sp?), or even a slog over a helicarrier as it rests in the comforts of Hanger 21, afterburners ready to fry anyone underneath. Now, this may be a personal preference that not everyone shares, but since i played the Red Faction as a kid, i have been an absolute glutton for environmental destruction, and the ability to collapse the tower on Shanghai STILL makes me smile like an idiot as the enemy team scrambles to jump off of it.

The Gunplay is pretty much what you'd expect from any multiplayer shooter, though the weapons can be changed to fit any situation you may need them for. With this i will say that it sucks to have thermal sights be unlocked exclusively through Battlepacks, but they give you a whole shitload at the start of the game. 

The Community is.. interesting for lack of a better word, i've seen the odd white supremacist (usually kicked for being and i uote: "A Racist Cuck"), A very large amount of people with Anime Icons (Take em or leave em, they can be great or terrible), and lastly, the Furries. With Furries i treat them the same way i do when i see them in real life, avoid them. While in real life it's because i'd prefer not to talk to anyone who wants to fuck animals in the same way i prefer not to interact with racists, but here in battlefield I have another reason: If you see anyone with an icon that is furry porn or anything similar, run for the fucking hills because they'll fill you full of holes faster than a swiss cheese fetishist.

Furry Jokes aside, this is the only AAA FPS title that i can honestly and genuinely recommend buying right now, and if you're the type to bitch about having to install PB and the Origin Launcher, you're probably the same type of person to cry about getting spawn killed because you keep choosing to spawn on your surrounded teammate.

Thanks for taking the time to read this, hope to see you on the battlefield

title: Battlefield 4
review: This game is one of the best shooters ever made in my opinion. Even after 7 years being released and COD releasing Modern Warfare and Dice releasing other battlefields they still cant hold a candle or create the magic that this team of developers have done. To the epic battles and open world feeling that this game creates, everything is destructible from the buildings to the streets. Just make sure you download the new version of punk-buster and you will have 100's of hours of fun that is the only reason why it has mixed reviews on steam. I been playing all day and there are 10-15 servers that are full. That is truly saying something if your game is been out for almost a decade and people are still playing. If your looking for a breath of fresh air and have been burnt out on COD and other games give this a try.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
So I was super hype about this game coming to steam but that hype ended rather quickly.

I love battlefield but the whole servers being run by admin are quite annoying.

I literally joined a server that said you will get banned if you use vehicles and or any type of launcher. Which is stupid.

On the other hand I seen alot of admins ban people for no reason just because they can. Their are already not that many servers, so if someone gets banned on multiple servers they become even more limited for what they can play.

I know some people like these operation locker 24/7 and gomund 24/7 servers but i cant stand them. The wise thing would be to avoid these servers, but they are always populated. I wanted to play on DLC maps along with vanilla maps but when i look for servers like those, they are low in numbers which is discouraging considering the dlc is good. SO ALL IN ALL im pretty much forced to join the Vanilla maps only server with stupid rules, or The server that bans just because they can.

SO I believed the safest route is to just refund the game and move elsewhere. I am a big battlefield fan but the fact servers run by admins only and no longer officials is a no for me. The admins have too much power. Some of ya'll like that but I definately dont. So I'll just wait for the newer battlefield game to come out. I also dont like BFV that much. IT was OK. I prefer modern battlefield and since its been so long, Its not as populated as it used to be.

For those who are enjoying the game, I am glad you can find some fun in it because it really is a good game. But as mentioned above, I just can't unfortunately.

This review is mainly for the new comers who are thinking about getting this on Steam.

Sadly I am going to have to not recommend due to the above mentioned...

title: Battlefield 4

If Battlefield 3 is hands-down the best Battlefield in the series, BF4 is the most definitive version of it. 60-tick servers, better balance and more variety of weapons/maps/modes/vehicles than BF3 as well as better environmental destruction, Battlefield 4 is personally my all-time favorite. And to anybody out there in the shit-bucket army, do help the new Steam-noobs in this game. I know the skill-gap is atrociously wide given it's a 6+ year old game, but squad-play goes a long way in this game.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
Battlefield 4 is a great game in of itself. But the implementation to Steam is horrendous... 
-The Punkbuster service that comes with the game's download do not work and you have to manually download the newest version if you want to play online.
-The achievements do not transfer over to Steam. 
-Many players have reported netcode issues between the base Origin and Steam versions. 

Do not be fooled: If you buy on Steam, you're just buying a placeholder for Origin. The game still requires an EA/Origin account and must launch through Origin to play. So chances are that you'd be better off buying this on Origin and placing a shortcut for yourself on Steam.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
If you ask yourself, if you shall buy it or not (if you already own itm like I did), please mention:

You can add it to your existing account and play with your achivements as long as you do not own [b]Battlefield 4 Premiumedition[/b] (you can own BF4 + Premiumpass), but you will lose one key effectivly

You [b]can not use your origin installation[/b] any longer, if you do not want to waste 60 gigs of memory, but you can move your origin intalltion into your steam game directory.

You won't be able to unlock every single item. There are some DogTag's which are Event-Exkulive like the "I was there" Dog Tag ( have to say I'm till today - now, 7 years late - mad about my self not to have the game bought at GameStop  with my GamesCom exclustive tag.)

If you have origin already installed, steam will install a "second" origin as well as a new PunkBustr.


[b]If you now ask yourself, why on earth should I play 20 bucks if I bought it on release for 120, then don't buy it.[/b]

title: Battlefield 4
review:
I started playing at release and was never online on steam because of it. I quit 4-ish years ago, so i'm glad to see it on steam because I started playing again on a new account when quarantine hit. It's just as much fun as when I left! Plenty of servers and players, so don't be scared of buying a dead game. 
I have over 700 in-game hours and would gladly make it many more. I also didn't buy premium on my new account so 20 euro's for the premium edition is really really good, even if you already have the standard edition it would save you 30 bucks.
You do need to search for the Punkbuster drivers yourself, because for some reason they pre install the old ones for you... 

Imo the best Battlefield game out there, had a rough start at launch and now again with releasing on Steam, but that is all fixed now and definitely worth your money!

title: Battlefield 4
review:
I remember playin' this game back when I got it on my ragged ol' Xbox 360 all the way back in like... 2013. Played the heck out of it. Now, booting it up on my PC with better graphics, a nice FPS, a good surround headset, and 64 man servers, well it is quite a walk down memory lane. 

Setting my personal attachments aside though, the game seems to run great and the servers are populated. If you've never experienced this game, I'd really recommend it if you're looking for something with a bit more depth than a twitch shooter like CoD but still want something simple enough and enjoyable. The battlefield is chaotic and surprisingly immersive, and there's a ton of weapons, attachments, and customization to keep you occupied. Overall it is still a fun ride even after all these years, at least for me.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
It's Battlefield 4 (the best modern battlefield) on Steam. Annoying punkbuster issue and forcing to open through origin aside, it's a great (still fairly active, with several servers of 64 player conquest completely full right now at 11:26 pm central us time) game that is tons of fun and rewarding to learn. A great entry point to the series as well for new players. I am including another review from a fellow BF4 fan below so that if you get the punkbuster issue where it kicks you from the game after a couple minutes in the server you can easily fix and play it until they patch the newest version in. Probably be tomorrow or something hopefully. It's super easy to fix though. Check it out:

you've gotta go to https://www.evenbalance.com/pbsetup.php and download the version you need and then in the top left of the application click 'Add a Game" click in the drop-down menu "Battlefield 4" and then install it and follow the steps. Make sure your game is closed and then open it back up again.

title: Battlefield 4
review: as cool as it is to see this game pushed onto steam after god knows how many years, i hate to say it but there is no point in buying this. if you do purchase this you will be stuck with not only downloading punkbuster, but you will have to install the origin launcher AND create an account if you never used their services before. it is completely counter intuitive and ruins the whole reason to buy this on steam. What's the point in buying this game on steam when you still have to run it through origin, that's like taking my copy of titanfall 2 and adding it as a non-steam game. but if you're cool with running two launchers to play one game than go right ahead and enjoy but this is not for me and i doubt others would take the time to go through that process as well.

title: Battlefield 4
review:
extended guide on how to correctly install PB if you are getting kicked:

1. Download the PunkBuster client: https://www.evenbalance.com/pbsetup.php/
2. install it. (duh)
3. Once it is installed, a window called PBSetup should be opened - Click Add a Game, select Battlefield 4 and it should automatically find your BF4 installation. If it doesn't, just browse and select the folder you installed BF4 in.
4. Click Add Game. PBSetup should be downloading the updated client/server versions.

Enjoy BF4 on steam, and here's to hope the EA gets rid of origin.

https://www.evenbalance.com/pbsetup.php
